800 x 480 |Dimensions = 245 mm x 196mm x 44 mm |Weight = 1.3 kg [2.9 pounds] }} The '''Classmate PC''', formerly known as '''Eduwise''', is [[Intel]]'s entry into the market for low-cost [[personal computer]]s for children in the developing world. It is in some respects similar to the [[One Laptop Per Child]] (OLPC) [[trade association]]'s [[Children's Machine]] (XO), which has a similar target market. Although made for profit, the production of the Classmate PC is considered an [[Information and Communication Technologies for Development]] project. The device falls into the newly defined category of [[netbook]]s. ==Intel World Ahead Program== Intelâs World Ahead Program was established May 2006. The program designed a platform for low cost laptops that third party manufacturers could use to produce low cost machines under their own respective brands. The Classmate PC is a reference design by Intel. Intel does not build the subnotebooks, but does produce the chips that power them. The reference design is then used by [[original equipment manufacturers|original equipment manufacturers (OEMs)]] worldwide to build their own branded Classmate PC. ==Technology== Lenovo and Intel launched a new Classmate PC{{cite news|last=DeCarlo|first=Matthew|title=Lenovo launches Classmate+ academic notebook|url=http://www.techspot.com/news/42768-lenovo-launches-classmate-academic-notebook.html|accessdate=21 October 2011|newspaper=Tech Spot|date=10 March 2011}} in 2011. Intel has had various partners with its iterations of the Classmate PC. Recently, the company has signed up Lenovo as a partner for the latest model, the Classmate+ PC. Reviews of the machine say that it's faster and more tamper proof{{cite web|last=Dawson|first=Christopher|title=Classmate PC: Faster, stronger, more|url=http://www.zdnet.com/news/intel-unveils-tablet-classmate-pc-design/261656?tag=btxcsim|publisher=ZD Net|accessdate=21 October 2011}} . The Lenovo carry handle is firmly in place at the back of the Classmate+ PC and it's powered by one of Intel's Atom processors, in this case a single core 1.6GHz Atom N455 which is paired with Intel's NM10 chipset. It will also come with up to 2GB of RAM, a standard netbook style 10.1-inch LCD screen, an option of either an 8 or 16GB SSD or a 160 or 250GB hard drive. Other features include 802.11b/g/n Wi-Fi, 10/100Mbit Ethernet, a 1.3Megapixel webcam, three USB 2.0 ports, a memory card reader, a D-sub connector and a pair of audio jacks. Lenovo will supply three different battery packs for the Classmate+ PC, a standard 3-cell unit which is said to deliver 3-3.5h battery life depending on whether it's configured with a hard drive or SSD, a 4400mAh 6-cell pack good for between 7-7.5h and finally a 5200mAh high density 6-cell battery pack good for up to 8.5-9h of usage. The Classmate+ PC will only be available to qualified education and government customers through Lenovo or its channel It comes with a camera and an accelerometer. ==Intel-Powered Convertible Classmate PC== The Intel-Powered Convertible Classmate PC had its official release at [[CES]] in January 2009 and was aimed at students, teachers, and parents. The Convertible Classmate can be converted from a traditional laptop to a tablet PC to allow children to write and draw more naturally. This model was designed by [[TEAMS Design]] [[Shanghai]] and won several design awards such as the Appliance Design EID Award{{cite web|title=2011 Excellence in Design Awards|url=http://www.appliancedesign.com/HTML/EID/59b1367daf848010VgnVCM100000f932a8c0|work=EID Awards|publisher=Appliance Design|accessdate=21 October 2011}}, 2008 Spark Award and {{cite web|title= Spark Award 2008|url=http://www.sparkawards.com/Galleries/09_Entries.htm?appid=1948|publisher=Spark Awards|accessdate=21 October 2011}}[[International Forum Design|IF]] 2008 China Award{{cite web|title=iF design award china 2008|url=http://www.ifdesign.de/beitragsdetails_e.html?offset=19&sprache=1&award_id=161&beitrag_id=42577|publisher=International Design Forum Hanover|accessdate=21 October 2011}}. The initial model includes the following: *Dual mode: tablet mode and traditional laptop mode. *When open like a traditional laptop, the screen swivels 180 degrees for easier sharing. *1.6 GHz Intel Atom processor *1 GB RAM (2 GB max) *60GB Hard Disk Drive (PATA 1.8", ZIF socket) *8.9 inch touch screen & advanced palm-resting technology. *Allows for writing or drawing directly on the screen. *Built-in camera rotates 180Â° to enable students to interact in a new way *Portability: Carrying handle, lightweight and compact size. *Water-resistant keyboard *Education-specific features and touch-optimized software *SD Card Reader; documentation says that you can boot the system off an SD card, or a standard USB thumbdrive *Comes with either Windows XP installed (standard) or Windows XP Professional (an extra $186 on the 2go) ===Software=== Intel announced that its device would run either [[Linux]] or [[Windows XP|Windows XP Professional]]. Intel is not using [[Windows XP Embedded]] as initially planned. Intel has been actively working with various international and local Linux distributions in various countries. Intel has worked with [[Mandriva]] to customize their Linux distribution for Classmate PC.{{cite web|url=http://www.desktoplinux.com/news/NS4146178789.html |title=Low-cost student laptops to run Mandriva Linux |publisher=Desktoplinux.com |date=2007-03-29 |accessdate=2011-02-15}}{{cite web|author=Mandriva on Classmate PC: A Linux Education for Everyone |url=http://www.olpcnews.com/software/operating_system/mandriva_classmate_linux.html |title=Mandriva on Classmate PC: A Linux Education for Everyone |publisher=OLPC News |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}} Currently, the Intel powered classmate PC has been shown to run the following Linux distributions: *[[Mandriva Linux]](International & Pan-European Linux operating system mandriva.com) *[[Metasys]] (International Syst in Brazil) ===Latin America=== In [[Latin America]], contingent upon the receipt of sufficient international fund monies, the [[Mexico|Mexican]] and [[Brazil]]ian governments are evaluating whether to buy Intel's or the OLPC's laptop.{{cite web|url=http://news.digitaltrends.com/article11875.html |title=Intel to Compete with OLPC in Brazil â Computing News â Digital Trends |publisher=News.digitaltrends.com |date=2006-12-07 |accessdate=2011-02-15}} Regardless of the hardware chosen, the Brazilian government announced that it would use the Linux operating system.{{cite web|last=Paul |first=Ryan |url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20061206-8371.html |title=Intel and OLPC compete for edu-laptop market in Brazil |publisher=Arstechnica.com |date=2006-12-06 |accessdate=2011-02-15}} It has been confirmed that Intel will be shipping the Laptops with [[Mandriva Linux]], Discovery 2007 edition{{cite web|url=http://www.linuxelectrons.com/news/mobile/intels-classmate-mobile-pc-ships-south-america |title=Intel's 'Classmate' Mobile PC Ships to South America |publisher=LinuxElectrons |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}} as well as the ''Classmate 2.0'' [[Linux distribution]] by the Brazilian company [[Metasys]]. About the end of 2009, Argentina's government planned to give all the public high school students one of these netbooks. 740 million U$S will be used to give all public schools routers and infrastructure to reduce the digital gap around the country. ===Africa=== In [[Africa]], Intel has also started shipping to [[Libya]] as part of its deal of supplying 150,000 units.{{cite web|url=http://tech.monstersandcritics.com/news/article_1370177.php/Intel_supplies_Libya_with_150000_Classmates |title=Intel supplies Libya with 150,000 Classmates |publisher=Tech.monstersandcritics.com |date=2007-10-31 |accessdate=2011-02-15}} In Seychelles, Classmate PC were supplied to primary schools as part of Sheikh Khalifa ICT project Seychelles 2010. ===Asia=== In [[Asia]], it has been available in [[Indonesia]] since early March 2008, through two local brands: [[AXIOO International|Axioo]] and [[Zyrex]]. In Q4 of 2009 will be introducing the 10.1" versions of both netbooks at retail. ==Comparisons with OLPC project== The Classmate PC represents Intel's competitive response to the [[OLPC]] XO, whose unusually low prices and use of [[AMD]] chips threatened to steal market share from Intel and other major manufacturers. Although Intel initially criticized the XO laptops for their lack of functionalityâIntel's Chairman of the Board, [[Craig Barrett (businessman)|Craig Barrett]], himself claimed consumers wanted the full functionality of a PCâthe Classmate PCs are currently being heavily marketed against the XO worldwide. Intel has already secured deals to sell hundreds of thousands of Classmate PCs to [[Libya]], [[Nigeria]] and [[Pakistan]], the same developing countries the [[OLPC]] project had been targeting.Kraemer et al.: "One Laptop Per Child: Vision vs. Reality", ''Communications of the ACM'', June 2009. The goals of the Classmate PC project and the OLPC project have some differences. According to Intel: the Classmate PC aims to provide technology that fits into the larger, primarily Windows-based computing environment.{{cite web|url=http://download.intel.com/intel/worldahead/pdf/classmatepc_productbrief.pdf?iid=worldahead+ed_cmpc_pdf |title=Product Brief of the Classmate PC |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}} However, according to the OLPC, the XO breaks from the desktop metaphor to provide a UI ([[Sugar (desktop environment)|Sugar]]) that they feel is more suited to the educational needs of children.{{cite web|url=http://www.laptop.org/laptop/software/index.shtml |title=One Laptop per Child (OLPC), Software: XO Vision |publisher=Laptop.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-15}} While the OLPC uses hardware and software highly customized for the educational environment, Intel has argued that the developing world wants to have generic [[Personal computer|PCs]]. In December 2005, Intel publicly dismissed the XO as a 'gadget'.[http://web.archive.org/web/20051212065117/http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/SP263515.htm Reuters AlertNet â World's poorest don't want "$100 laptop" -Intel] Intel joined the OLPC project in July 2007 and was widely expected to work on a version of the project's laptop that used an Intel chip, only to pull out of the project in January 2008.
